channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: E.U. Toughens Visa Requirements for Russians, but Balks at Travel Ban
item.description: As European ministers debated new restrictions, a team of nuclear experts were on a mission to assess the safety of the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant, where shelling has raised the fear of a nuclear catastrophe.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: U.N. nuclear experts preparing to leave Kyiv for the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant on Wednesday.

item.title: The West’s Illusions About Gorbachev and the Victory of Liberalism
item.description: As the Soviet Union’s final leader, Mikhail Gorbachev dreamed of a “common European home,” but three decades later that tantalizing idea remains out of reach.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Mikhail Gorbachev, when he led the Soviet Union, addressing the U.N. General Assembly in December 1988.

item.title: A Draft for Russia’s Army? Putin Opts for Domestic Stability Instead.
item.description: Western officials are puzzled by the Russian leader’s decision to avoid mass conscription. But analysts say he is intent on maintaining a sense of normalcy to prevent any public backlash.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Russian conscripts boarding a train to their garrisons in Omsk, Russia, in June. Conscripts serving their required year of military service are not fighting in Ukraine, according to the Kremlin.

item.title: ‘Absolute Warfare’: Cartels Terrorize Mexico as Security Forces Fall Short
item.description: The president disbanded the Federal Police and created the National Guard to tackle soaring violence, but three years later, criminal cartels have expanded their reach.
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the National Guard providing security at a crime scene in Celaya last week.

item.title: Families of Israelis Killed at Munich Olympics Reach Compensation Deal
item.description: The Israeli and German governments announced an agreement after the families said they would boycott a memorial observing the 1972 attack over what they called insufficient recompense.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: Ankie Spitzer last month in Ramat Hasharon, Israel, with the bullet-scarred necklace her husband, Andrei Spitzer, was wearing at the time of his death at the 1972 Munich Olympics.

item.title: Putin Issues Brief Condolences as World Reacts to Gorbachev’s Death
item.description: People reflected on the death of Mikhail Gorbachev, the last Soviet leader, who was lionized abroad as a hero of liberalism, but castigated by many in Russia for bringing about the end of the Soviet empire.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Mikhail Gorbachev, Who Oversaw the End of the Soviet Union, Is Dead at 91
item.description: Adopting principles of glasnost and perestroika, he weighed the legacy of seven decades of Communist rule and set a new course, presiding over the end of the Cold War and the dissolution of the U.S.S.R.
item.dc:creator: Marilyn Berger
item.media:credit: Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times
item.media:description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev had a profound effect on his time: In little more than six tumultuous years, he lifted the Iron Curtain, transforming the map of Europe and the political climate of the world.

item.title: A Frontline Shadow Economy: Ukrainian Units Swap Tanks and Artillery
item.description: Most of the bartering involves items captured from Russian troops, which are exchanged for urgently needed supplies. “Let’s just call it a simplification of bureaucracy,” one soldier said.
item.media:description: Repairing a captured Russian armored personnel carrier in the Donetsk region of Ukraine last week.

item.title: With War in Ukraine, Putin Tries to Unravel Gorbachev’s Legacy
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin calls the end of the Soviet Union a “genuine tragedy” for Russia, and he blamed Mikhail S. Gorbachev for bending to the demands of a treacherous and duplicitous West.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Moscow in 2000.

item.title: Vancouver Moves to Sue Big Oil After Deadly Fires and Disastrous Floods
item.description: A potential lawsuit by Vancouver would be the first in Canada to target the fossil fuel industry’s role in climate change.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Melissa Renwick for The New York Times
item.media:description: The scars left by a wildfire that destroyed the small town of Lytton, British Columbia.

item.title: Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia Is Hospitalized With Covid
item.description: A towering figure in his country’s politics, Mahathir Mohamad was admitted to the hospital for monitoring, and says he’s contemplating another election run at age 97.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.media:description: Mahathir Mohamad, a former prime minister of Malaysia, at his office in Kuala Lumpur in August.

item.title: Typhoon Hinnamnor Brings High Winds to Japanese Islands
item.description: Forecasters say the storm is the Northern Hemisphere’s strongest tropical cyclone of the year. It was expected to bypass Taiwan and head toward the Korean Peninsula later this week.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: After Clashes Kill 24, Iraq Cleric Works to Defuse Tension in Baghdad
item.description: With no functioning government and no common ground, tensions among Shiite political factions have become a deadly matter in Baghdad this week.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:description: Fighters from a group linked with the Shiite cleric Muqtada al-Sadr clashed with Iraqi security forces, including members of Iran-backed militias, in Baghdad on Tuesday.

item.title: Lisa LaFlamme Ouster Sets Off Outcry in Canada
item.description: The chief executive of a Canadian news network pushed back against allegations that sex, age or gray hair were factors in the abrupt dismissal of the veteran journalist, Lisa LaFlamme.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: Lisa LaFlamme after winning a Best News Anchor award in April.

item.title: China May Have Committed ‘Crimes Against Humanity’ in Xinjiang, U.N. Says
item.description: The organization’s human rights office delivered its much-delayed report minutes before Michelle Bachelet, the U.N. high commissioner for human rights, was to leave office.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce and Austin Ramzy
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A security guard at a detention center in Yarkant County, Xinjiang, China, last year. Delays to the U.N. report about abuses in the region prompted fierce pushback from rights groups.

item.title: Bitter Race to Lead U.K. Is Ending With Little to Offer for Economic Ills
item.description: The contest to succeed Boris Johnson as Conservative Party leader and prime minister has often seemed divorced from Britain’s fast-growing problems.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Liz Truss, the foreign secretary and front-runner to replace Boris Johnson as prime minister, at Wembley Arena in London on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: How Authoritarians See Mikhail Gorbachev
item.description: Plus the decline in American life expectancy and the latest on Typhoon Hinnamnor.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Mikhail Gorbachev, left, with Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping in 1989. Both oversaw reforms that later leaders worked to undo.

item.title: E.U. Moves to Restrict Russian Visas, But Does Not Ban Them
item.description: The suspension of a 2007 agreement with Russia will make visas cost more, require more paperwork and involve longer delays.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Russian travelers waited at a passport control queue at the Niujamaa crossing in Finland, on that country’s border with Russia. Finland and Estonia’s land crossings have seen most of the traffic of Russian travelers into the European Union since the beginning of the war in Ukraine.

item.title: Our Latest Covid Poll
item.description: Americans on the left end of the political spectrum have become less anxious about Covid.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Gabby Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Times Square in July.

item.title: Read Your Way Through Mexico City
item.description: Juan Villoro, who spent over two decades perfecting one book about Mexico City, recommends reading on the city he loves. “Mexico is too complex,” a visitor said. “It needs to be read.”
item.dc:creator: Juan Villoro
item.category: Horizontal Vertigo: A City Called Mexico (Book)
On the Plain of Snakes: A Mexican Journey (Book)

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Mikhail Gorbachev is dead at 91.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times
item.media:description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev had a profound effect on his time: In little more than six tumultuous years, he lifted the Iron Curtain, transforming the map of Europe and the political climate of the world.

item.title: The experts’ convoy of armored S.U.V.s traveled toward an active battlefield.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Marc Santora and Lynsey Addario
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rafael Grossi, the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, speaking to reporters in Kyiv early Wednesday before heading to the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant.

item.title: US Life Expectancy Falls Again in ‘Historic’ Setback
item.description: The decline during the pandemic is the sharpest in nearly 100 years, hitting Native American and Alaska Native communities particularly hard.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:description: A patient who died of Covid was removed from an I.C.U. in Cleveland, Ohio.

item.title: How Gorbachev’s Legacy of Perestroika Vanished
item.description: His vision of a “common European home” stretching from Vladivostok to Lisbon has been replaced by a Russia increasingly isolated from the rest of Europe.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, visiting the Great Wall of China near Beijing in May 1989.

item.title: How Reagan and Bush Overcame Skepticism to Collaborate With Gorbachev
item.description: Mr. Gorbachev was charming and presented himself as a reformer, but neither Ronald Reagan nor George Bush was convinced he was for real. They would both be proved wrong.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev with President Ronald Reagan and President-elect George Bush in 1988.

item.title: Putin Sees the War as Part of His Battle to Undo Gorbachev’s Legacy
item.description: For Mr. Putin, the end of the Soviet Union was the “greatest geopolitical catastrophe of the century,” caused by the weak nerves of a leader too willing to appease the treacherous West.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Schleswig, Germany, in 2004.

item.title: Gorbachev’s Op-Eds in The Times
item.description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev wrote often about issues including world affairs and climate change. He also mourned former President Ronald Reagan and the former British prime minister, Margaret Thatcher.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Experts in Ukraine to Inspect Nuclear Plant in Battle Zone
item.description: A senior adviser to Ukraine’s president said that key aspects of the negotiations between the international team, Ukraine and Russia were in question, including a safe route to the plant itself.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainians fleeing Russian-occupied villages arriving in Zaporizhzhia on Tuesday. Shelling there fueled fears of a possible disaster at a nuclear power plant.

item.title: Solomon Islands Suspends Visits by Foreign Navies, Raising Concerns Over China
item.description: The move comes after top U.S. officials visited the Pacific nation to bolster ties and deliver warnings over its new security agreement with China.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: The U.S. combat ship Oakland visited Honiara, the capital of the Solomon Islands, as part of a ceremony in early August marking the 80th anniversary of battles in World War II.

item.title: A Reporter’s Memories of Gorbachev, and That Pizza Hut Commercial
item.description: Anatoly Kurmanaev, a New York Times reporter, recalls a childhood forever changed by a man with a distinctive birthmark.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Moscow in 1991.

item.title: Another ship earmarked for humanitarian aid has left Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Security personnel by grain silos at the Odesa Port in July in Odesa, Ukraine.

item.title: Main Target of Russian Mercenaries in Africa Is Civilians, Report Says
item.description: Newly released data seen by The New York Times suggests that the Kremlin-affiliated Wagner Group plays a central role in violence against civilians in the Central African Republic and Mali.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Wagner operatives at the Mopti airport, in central Mali, in February.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: China Plans the Communist Party’s 20th Congress
item.description: Plus India’s Supreme Court widens its definition of family and floods devastate Pakistan.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China during a national award ceremony in Beijing on Tuesday.

item.title: Scenes from the Devastating Flooding in Pakistan
item.description: Months of rain has swollen rivers and inundated communities across Pakistan, killing more than 1,100 people.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: U.N. Race Panel Sounds the Alarm on Abortion Access in the U.S.
item.description: The influential committee called on the Biden administration to safeguard access for minorities and to address a host of issues on race relations.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:description: Atlanta’s mayor, Andre Dickens, center, was a member of the U.S. delegation appearing during the hearing held by the United Nations’ Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination in Geneva this month.

item.title: Paxlovid Cuts Covid Deaths Among Older People, Israeli Study Finds
item.description: Among patients under 65, however, the drug made little difference in hospitalization or death rates.
item.dc:creator: Roni Rabin
item.media:description: According to the new Israeli study, the medication was highly effective when administered to individuals 65 and over.

item.title: The European Union plans to give 5.5 million iodine tablets to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Irina Marchenko, 36, and her two children, Klim, 1, and Daniel, 13, collected tablets from Sveta Kovalenko, 51, to take in case of exposure to radiation in the event of a nuclear catastrophe, at a hospital in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: French Tax Collectors Use A.I. to Spot Thousands of Undeclared Pools
item.description: Algorithms combing through satellite photos found over 20,000 unreported swimming pools in a few regions, yielding an expected $10 million in taxes, and the system will soon go nationwide.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Francois Lo Presti/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Installing a swimming pool in northern France this month. The French government is using new technology to crack down on homeowners who fail to register pools to avoid higher property taxes.

item.title: India’s Top Court Says ‘Family’ Includes Same-Sex Couples and Others
item.description: The court declared that same-sex parents, single parents and blended families deserve equal treatment, the latest in a series of rulings pushing back on conservative social norms.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall and Hari Kumar
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: A family at a festival in New Delhi. The Supreme Court’s judgment is final, but its enforcement abilities are limited, and many family matters are decided out of court.

item.title: Chris Dawson, Subject of ‘Teacher’s Pet’ Podcast, Is Found Guilty of Wife’s Murder
item.description: Mr. Dawson was on trial in Australia. His wife, Lynette Dawson, went missing in 1982, and a popular podcast brought new attention to the cold case.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: Chris Dawson, second from left, arriving at court in Sydney, Australia, on Tuesday.

item.title: Vatican Criticizes Russia’s Invasion of Ukraine for the First Time
item.description: Condemning the invasion as “unacceptable,” the Vatican sought to calm a controversy caused by earlier remarks by Pope Francis.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: The pope’s words, the Vatican said, “are to be read as a voice raised in defense of human life and the values attached to it, and not as taking a political stance.”

item.title: U.N. Nuclear Inspectors Are in Ukraine to Visit the Zaporizhzhia Plant
item.description: As artillery strikes continued near the complex, the inspectors could reach the nuclear plant as soon as Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A photo provided by the Ukrainian Presidential Press Service shows President Volodymyr Zelensky meeting Rafael Mariano Grossi, the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, in Kyiv.

item.title: Xi Jinping Poised to Win 5 More Years at China’s Congress in October
item.description: Xi Jinping is poised to win five more years in power at the congress, a choreographed ritual that will offer a glimpse of China’s broad policy direction.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.media:description: Xi Jinping at the last Communist Party congress in Beijing, in 2017.

item.title: A Poorer Generation
item.description: Americans under 40 have had to cope with a worse economy than earlier generations. How should it affect the debate over Biden’s debt-relief plan?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Student loan forgiveness advocates attend a press conference in front of the White House in Washington, DC, last week.

item.title: Exploring Spain’s Arab Influence
item.description: Exploring the country’s Arab influence is an impossibly romantic journey, involving palaces with intricate geometric designs, castles and grand mosques reconfigured by Christians into cathedrals.
item.dc:creator: Nina Burleigh
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:credit: Emilio Parra Doiztua for The New York Times
item.media:description: Córdoba’s Mosque-Cathedral, or La Mezquita, was one of the first and grandest mosques in Europe.

item.title: For Singapore’s Gay Men, Repeal of Sex Ban Brings Hope After Years of Pain
item.description: The government confirmed that it would get rid of the colonial-era law, but said it would also move to protect the definition of marriage from being challenged in court.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Ore Huiying for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gay bar in Singapore on Thursday, after the government announced it would repeal a law banning consensual sex between men.

item.title: How German Companies Are Staring Down Putin’s Threat to Cut Off Gas
item.description: Industrial producers across Germany are coming up with unique ways to cut their dependence on natural gas as Russia’s war in Ukraine keeps prices high.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Patrick Junker for The New York Times
item.media:description: A power plant burning coal in Wilhelmshaven, Germany. Coal-fired plants, many of which were destined to be shut down, have been revived by manufacturers seeking an alternative to expensive Russian natural gas.

item.title: The Animal Translators
item.description: Scientists are using machine learning to eavesdrop on naked mole rats, fruit bats, crows and whales — and to communicate back.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Felix Schmitt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Naked mole rats live in large, underground colonies and have an elaborate vocal repertoire.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Ukraine launches a southern offensive.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian service members riding back from a position near the Kherson front line this month.

item.title: First Shipment of Iranian Drones Arrives in Russia
item.description: Russia could deploy the drones in its war against Ukraine to conduct air-to-surface attacks, carry out electronic warfare and identify targets, according to U.S. officials.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: In this photo released by the Iranian Army on Thursday, a drone is launched as part of a military drill in Iran.

item.title: Ukraine Announces Offensive in Kherson, as Inspectors Head to Nuclear Plant
item.description: The scale of Ukraine’s push in the Kherson region was unclear, but it has vowed for months to mount a counteroffensive to retake territory seized by Russia.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers of Ukraine’s Territorial Defense Forces at a frontline position near Bakhmut, in the eastern Donetsk region, on Monday.

item.title: In Brazil, the Last Member of an Isolated Indigenous Tribe Dies
item.description: Known as the “Man of the Hole,” the last member of an Indigenous group was found dead this month, marking the first recorded disappearance of an isolated tribe in the country.
item.dc:creator: Flávia Milhorance and André Spigariol
item.media:description: A still image from a video provided by the Brazilian government showing one of the huts built by the “Man of the Hole” in Rondônia State in 2018.

item.title: Deadly Floods Devastate an Already Fragile Pakistan
item.description: More than 1,100 have died as record monsoon rains inundate the country, washing away bridges, roads and crop fields. Much of Pakistan is underwater.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak, Raymond Zhong and Ihsanullah Tipu Mehsud
item.media:description: Army troops evacuated people from a flood-hit area in Rajanpur, Punjab district, Pakistan, on Saturday.

item.title: Greenland’s Melting Ice Sheet Could Raise Sea Levels by Nearly a Foot: Study
item.description: The study reached a more drastic conclusion than earlier assessments in part because it used a different method to gauge ice loss.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao
item.media:description: An iceberg in Baffin Bay near Pituffik, Greenland, in July.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: China Charges 28 People in Beating of Women
item.description: Plus the controversy over seabed mining and the geopolitical drama surrounding Taiwan’s microchips
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: A still image taken from a video showing two women on the ground after being assaulted by a group of men in Tangshan, China, in June. On Monday the authorities announced that charges had been filed in the case as part of a broader investigation of gang activity in the city.

item.title: Angola’s Ruling Party, MPLA, Retains Power in Tightest Election Yet
item.description: The Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola won in the general election with the lowest margin since coming to power in 1975.
item.dc:creator: Gilberto Neto and Lynsey Chutel
item.category: Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola
National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
item.media:description: President João Lourenço of Angola celebrated his election victory at his party’s headquarters in Luanda, Angola, on Monday.

item.title: Be ‘Less Squeamish’ About Drinking Recycled Wastewater, British Official Says
item.description: As droughts become more frequent, drinking water that has been reprocessed from sewage treatment is the future, the head of Britain’s Environment Agency said.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: A sewage treatment plant in Rickmansworth, England. Toilet-to-tap recycling is “perfectly safe and healthy, but not something many people fancy,” the head of Britain’s Environment Agency wrote this week.

item.title: Did My Cat Just Hit On Me? An Adventure in Pet Translation
item.description: Entrepreneurs are aiming to put A.I.-powered pet translation tools into our pockets.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
